elements.content: The metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) UiO-66-NH2 and HKUST-1 were adhered to chemically inert polypropylene (PP) fibrous mats with poly­(ether-block-amide), aka PEBA or PeBax, using a phase inversion technique. Two types of PeBax were used to investigate the effects of a hydrophilic vs hydrophobic treatment on uptake and permeation properties of the chemical warfare agent simulant 2-chloroethyl ethyl sulfide (CEES). Furthermore, the underlying PP fiber density was altered to understand CEES permeation properties. It was found that using the hydrophobic PeBax 2533 and a higher fiber density led to better barrier properties, with the best material providing ∼250 min protection to a permeation rate of 0.1 μg/min/cm2 in comparison to ∼150 min for the activated carbon fiber Stedcarb. CEES uptake ranged from ∼1.0 to 2.4 mol/kg for composites in comparison to 3.6 mol/kg for the pure MOF. Furthermore, the technique allowed for incorporation of different MOFs, and even a mixture of MOFs, on the same fiber substrate. Finally, the PeBax formulation was able to stabilize HKUST-1 against moisture, potentially opening the door for applications of this MOF in high-humidity environments.
elements.clean_text: The metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) UiO-66-NH2 and HKUST-1 were adhered to chemically inert polypropylene (PP) fibrous mats with poly(ether-block-amide), aka PEBA or PeBax, using a phase inversion technique. Two types of PeBax were used to investigate the effects of a hydrophilic vs hydrophobic treatment on uptake and permeation properties of the chemical warfare agent simulant 2-chloroethyl ethyl sulfide (CEES). Furthermore, the underlying PP fiber density was altered to understand CEES permeation properties. It was found that using the hydrophobic PeBax 2533 and a higher fiber density led to better barrier properties, with the best material providing ~250 min protection to a permeation rate of 0.1 μg/min/cm2 in comparison to ~150 min for the activated carbon fiber Stedcarb. CEES uptake ranged from ~1.0 to 2.4 mol/kg for composites in comparison to 3.6 mol/kg for the pure MOF. Furthermore, the technique allowed for incorporation of different MOFs, and even a mixture of MOFs, on the same fiber substrate. Finally, the PeBax formulation was able to stabilize HKUST-1 against moisture, potentially opening the door for applications of this MOF in high-humidity environments.

elements.content: Protection against chemical warfare agents (CWAs) and toxic industrial chemicals (TICs) continues to be a necessity due to ongoing worldwide events, such as the “Salisbury Incident”, the recent chlorine tank explosion in Jordan, and more. To defend against these threats, personal protective equipment (PPE) is being developed by incorporating metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) onto fiber-based composites that are able to ab/adsorb and detoxify these dangerous chemicals. MOFs, which are highly porous materials composed of metal nodes connected by functionalized organic linkers, have been shown to provide extensive uptake and reaction toward a variety of toxic chemicals, including nerve agents, ammonia, chlorine, nitrogen dioxide, and more.
elements.clean_text: Protection against chemical warfare agents (CWAs) and toxic industrial chemicals (TICs) continues to be a necessity due to ongoing worldwide events, such as the "Salisbury Incident", the recent chlorine tank explosion in Jordan, and more. To defend against these threats, personal protective equipment (PPE) is being developed by incorporating metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) onto fiber-based composites that are able to ab/adsorb and detoxify these dangerous chemicals. MOFs, which are highly porous materials composed of metal nodes connected by functionalized organic linkers, have been shown to provide extensive uptake and reaction toward a variety of toxic chemicals, including nerve agents, ammonia, chlorine, nitrogen dioxide, and more.

elements.content: A significant amount of research has been dedicated to fabricating MOF-based composites via electrospinning through both MOF-first (i.e., MOFs are presynthesized and then incorporated into/onto fibers during polymer processing) and Fiber-first (i.e., MOFs are grown onto fibers after polymer processing) techniques. While electrospinning has been used successfully to form composites, often the total amount of MOF on the composite is limited, as the underlying amount of the polymer is relatively low due to thin fiber diameters. Furthermore, depending on how the MOF is incorporated, mechanical properties may be adversely affected as the MOF can disrupt chain packing within the fiber.
elements.clean_text: A significant amount of research has been dedicated to fabricating MOF-based composites via electrospinning through both MOF-first (i.e., MOFs are presynthesized and then incorporated into/onto fibers during polymer processing) and Fiber-first (i.e., MOFs are grown onto fibers after polymer processing) techniques. While electrospinning has been used successfully to form composites, often the total amount of MOF on the composite is limited, as the underlying amount of the polymer is relatively low due to thin fiber diameters. Furthermore, depending on how the MOF is incorporated, mechanical properties may be adversely affected as the MOF can disrupt chain packing within the fiber.

elements.content: To overcome some of these limitations, an alternative approach is to use a mechanically robust starting fabric, such as melt-blown polypropylene (PP), and attach MOFs using either covalent attachment or a “glue”. In this effort, we focus on the latter, using poly­(ether-block-amide) (PeBax) as an elastomeric adhesive to incorporate MOF onto the PP fiber mat through a phase inversion technique. Using phase inversion, as opposed to simply allowing the polymer film to dry, provides a hierarchical porosity for which toxic chemicals can easily diffuse to the active MOFs. We alter the density of the underlying PP textile as well as the type of PeBax used for incorporating UiO-66-NH2 onto PP to understand effects on composite performance against the CWA distilled mustard (HD) simulant 2-chloroethyl ethyl sulfide (CEES).
elements.clean_text: To overcome some of these limitations, an alternative approach is to use a mechanically robust starting fabric, such as melt-blown polypropylene (PP), and attach MOFs using either covalent attachment or a "glue". In this effort, we focus on the latter, using poly(ether-block-amide) (PeBax) as an elastomeric adhesive to incorporate MOF onto the PP fiber mat through a phase inversion technique. Using phase inversion, as opposed to simply allowing the polymer film to dry, provides a hierarchical porosity for which toxic chemicals can easily diffuse to the active MOFs. We alter the density of the underlying PP textile as well as the type of PeBax used for incorporating UiO-66-NH2 onto PP to understand effects on composite performance against the CWA distilled mustard (HD) simulant 2-chloroethyl ethyl sulfide (CEES).

elements.content: Composites were formed by dipcoating polypropylene (PP) swatches into PeBax solutions. The first solutions were made by mixing 0.5 g of UiO-66-NH2 in a scintillation vial containing 7 mL of ethanol and 3 mL of distilled water. The mixture was probe-sonicated for ∼30 s, and then 0.1 g of PeBax 1657 was added. The solution was stirred magnetically at 500 rpm and 70 °C for ∼2 h until all PeBax was dissolved. The same procedure was used for PeBax 2533, except pure isopropyl alcohol was used as the solvent instead of the ethanol/water mixture. PP swatches were submerged in each solution for ∼1 h, after which they were submerged in distilled water for phase inversion of PeBax to occur on the PP. Samples were dried at room temperature, and then placed in a vacuum oven at 75 °C for ∼24 h. Structures for PeBax 1657 and 2533 are shown in Figure S1.
elements.clean_text: Composites were formed by dipcoating polypropylene (PP) swatches into PeBax solutions. The first solutions were made by mixing 0.5 g of UiO-66-NH2 in a scintillation vial containing 7 mL of ethanol and 3 mL of distilled water. The mixture was probe-sonicated for ~30 s, and then 0.1 g of PeBax 1657 was added. The solution was stirred magnetically at 500 rpm and 70 °C for ~2 h until all PeBax was dissolved. The same procedure was used for PeBax 2533, except pure isopropyl alcohol was used as the solvent instead of the ethanol/water mixture. PP swatches were submerged in each solution for ~1 h, after which they were submerged in distilled water for phase inversion of PeBax to occur on the PP. Samples were dried at room temperature, and then placed in a vacuum oven at 75 °C for ~24 h. Structures for PeBax 1657 and 2533 are shown in Figure S1.

elements.content: Photographic and SEM images of the resulting composites from 30 gsm fabric after drying are shown in (note: see Figure S2 for SEM images of 70 gsm samples). Composites made from both PeBax 1657 (a hydrophilic variant) and PeBax 2533 (a hydrophobic variant) both had good dispersion of MOF throughout the textile. The PeBax 2533 was more hydrophobic due to the higher organic content (e.g., longer carbon chains) within the structure, as shown in Figure S1. TGA data (Figure S3a) were collected to determine the mass of MOF within the composites, and N2 isotherm data (Figure S3b) were collected to determine MOF accessibility within the composite. TGA data indicate that composites made using PeBax 1657 behave more like the baseline PP, while composites made using PeBax 2533 had characteristics more like the baseline MOF, in terms of initial mass loss due to solvent and onset of degradation. The mass of MOF on composites made with PeBax 2533 was higher than those for PeBax 1657, potentially because of the hydrophobic nature of PeBax 2533 being a better match for the nonpolar PP. Nitrogen uptake was commensurate with the TGA data, with the PeBax 2533 samples having higher uptake than the PeBax 1657 samples. For both types of composite, the mass of MOF calculated based on surface areas (Table S1) almost exactly matched the amount of MOF calculated from TGA data (), indicating that PeBax does not block access to the MOF pores.
elements.clean_text: Photographic and SEM images of the resulting composites from 30 gsm fabric after drying are shown in  (note: see Figure S2 for SEM images of 70 gsm samples). Composites made from both PeBax 1657 (a hydrophilic variant) and PeBax 2533 (a hydrophobic variant) both had good dispersion of MOF throughout the textile. The PeBax 2533 was more hydrophobic due to the higher organic content (e.g., longer carbon chains) within the structure, as shown in Figure S1. TGA data (Figure S3a) were collected to determine the mass of MOF within the composites, and N2 isotherm data (Figure S3b) were collected to determine MOF accessibility within the composite. TGA data indicate that composites made using PeBax 1657 behave more like the baseline PP, while composites made using PeBax 2533 had characteristics more like the baseline MOF, in terms of initial mass loss due to solvent and onset of degradation. The mass of MOF on composites made with PeBax 2533 was higher than those for PeBax 1657, potentially because of the hydrophobic nature of PeBax 2533 being a better match for the nonpolar PP. Nitrogen uptake was commensurate with the TGA data, with the PeBax 2533 samples having higher uptake than the PeBax 1657 samples. For both types of composite, the mass of MOF calculated based on surface areas (Table S1) almost exactly matched the amount of MOF calculated from TGA data (), indicating that PeBax does not block access to the MOF pores.

elements.content: Photographic and SEM images of the resulting composites from 30 gsm fabric after drying. PeBax 1657 on top row, PeBax 2533 on bottom row.
elements.clean_text: 1  Photographic and SEM images of the resulting composites from 30 gsm fabric after drying. PeBax 1657 on top row, PeBax 2533 on bottom row.

Next, the performance of the composites was assessed using microbreakthrough and permeation experiments, and results are shown in . Microbreakthrough testing, which measured the saturation concentration of the material for CEES, showed that PP70/P2533_UiO-66-NH2 provided the longest breakthrough time, followed by PP70/P1657_UiO-66-NH2 and then the two P30 samples. The results indicate that from a breakthrough time perspective, the density of the PP fiber mat was important, and the hydrophobicity of P2533 was advantageous for CEES uptake in comparison to the hydrophilic P1657. When the results are corrected for the mass used in the test (b), the initial breakthrough times for P70 samples were still higher than the P30 samples; however, the overall loadings were actually higher for the P30 samples on a mass basis (see Table S2 for CEES loadings).
elements.clean_text: Next, the performance of the composites was assessed using microbreakthrough and permeation experiments, and results are shown in . Microbreakthrough testing, which measured the saturation concentration of the material for CEES, showed that PP70/P2533_UiO-66-NH2 provided the longest breakthrough time, followed by PP70/P1657_UiO-66-NH2 and then the two P30 samples. The results indicate that from a breakthrough time perspective, the density of the PP fiber mat was important, and the hydrophobicity of P2533 was advantageous for CEES uptake in comparison to the hydrophilic P1657. When the results are corrected for the mass used in the test (b), the initial breakthrough times for P70 samples were still higher than the P30 samples; however, the overall loadings were actually higher for the P30 samples on a mass basis (see Table S2 for CEES loadings).

elements.content: CEES microbreakthrough data of composites on a (a) regular time and (b) weighted time basis.
elements.clean_text: 2  CEES microbreakthrough data of composites on a (a) regular time and (b) weighted time basis.

elements.content: Composites evaluated in a permeation cell indicate that barrier properties are impacted enormously by the fiber density and the type of PeBax used (). As with microbreakthrough results, the P70/P2533_UiO-66-NH2 material provided the best protection; P30/P2533_UiO-66-NH2 provided slightly lower protection, and both composites performed better than Stedcarb. Permeation times for all samples to a permeation rate of 0.1 μg/min/cm2 are summarized in Table S3. The samples made with PeBax2533 performed better than PeBax1657. This highlights the importance of the hydrophobic nature of the adhesive, which seemingly provided enhanced diffusion to the MOF sites within the barrier. Figure S4 shows the swatch and the portion of the swatch that changed color after contact with CEES. ATR-FTIR spectra support the covalent reaction of the MOF with CEES. There are two stretches associated with the primary aminea broad symmetric stretch ∼3300 cm–1 and a sharper asymmetric stretch at ∼3500 cm–1. After CEES exposure, the asymmetric stretch disappears due to the conversion of the primary amine to a secondary amine from reaction with CEES.
elements.clean_text: Composites evaluated in a permeation cell indicate that barrier properties are impacted enormously by the fiber density and the type of PeBax used (). As with microbreakthrough results, the P70/P2533_UiO-66-NH2 material provided the best protection; P30/P2533_UiO-66-NH2 provided slightly lower protection, and both composites performed better than Stedcarb. Permeation times for all samples to a permeation rate of 0.1 μg/min/cm2 are summarized in Table S3. The samples made with PeBax2533 performed better than PeBax1657. This highlights the importance of the hydrophobic nature of the adhesive, which seemingly provided enhanced diffusion to the MOF sites within the barrier. Figure S4 shows the swatch and the portion of the swatch that changed color after contact with CEES. ATR-FTIR spectra support the covalent reaction of the MOF with CEES. There are two stretches associated with the primary aminea broad symmetric stretch ~3300 cm-1 and a sharper asymmetric stretch at ~3500 cm-1. After CEES exposure, the asymmetric stretch disappears due to the conversion of the primary amine to a secondary amine from reaction with CEES.

elements.content: CEES permeation through PP/PeBax/UiO-66-NH2 composites. Data are presented as (a) effluent concentration and (b) permeation rate coming through the barriers.
elements.clean_text: 3  CEES permeation through PP/PeBax/UiO-66-NH2 composites. Data are presented as (a) effluent concentration and (b) permeation rate coming through the barriers.

elements.content: With the ability to fabricate composites made from UiO-66-NH2, we focused on similar techniques for the archetypal MOF HKUST-1, which has also shown promise for protection against toxic chemicals such as ammonia. SEM images (a) and energy dispersive X-ray (EDS, b) show good dispersion of very large HKUST-1 crystals throughout the fiber mat. Furthermore, we were able to demonstrate that the surface energy, and in particular the hydrophilicity/hydrophobicity, of the PP mat could be tailored by using either PeBax1657 or PeBax2533. As seen in the figures, water either immediately soaked into the fabric (PeBax1657, c) or formed droplets on the surface (PeBax2533, d). The strategy of incorporating MOFs after processing using PeBax as an adhesive also lends itself to incorporating multiple MOFs onto the same fiber substrate (Figure S5).
elements.clean_text: With the ability to fabricate composites made from UiO-66-NH2, we focused on similar techniques for the archetypal MOF HKUST-1, which has also shown promise for protection against toxic chemicals such as ammonia. SEM images (a) and energy dispersive X-ray (EDS, b) show good dispersion of very large HKUST-1 crystals throughout the fiber mat. Furthermore, we were able to demonstrate that the surface energy, and in particular the hydrophilicity/hydrophobicity, of the PP mat could be tailored by using either PeBax1657 or PeBax2533. As seen in the figures, water either immediately soaked into the fabric (PeBax1657, c) or formed droplets on the surface (PeBax2533, d). The strategy of incorporating MOFs after processing using PeBax as an adhesive also lends itself to incorporating multiple MOFs onto the same fiber substrate (Figure S5).

elements.content: (a) SEM image of HKUST-1 dispersed on PP30 and (b) associated EDS images. (c) PP30/P1657_HKUST-1 and (d) PP30/P2533_HKUST-1 with water dropped onto the surface.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) SEM image of HKUST-1 dispersed on PP30 and (b) associated EDS images. (c) PP30/P1657_HKUST-1 and (d) PP30/P2533_HKUST-1 with water dropped onto the surface.

elements.content: Finally, the stability of the composites was assessed in two different ways. HKUST-1 is known to be unstable toward moisture (both liquid and vapor). The PP30/P1657_HKUST-1 composite was submerged in liquid water for 24 h; as shown by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data shown in a, there was no difference in patterns before and after liquid water exposure, and the long-range order peaks associated with HKUST-1 remain intact for the sample. Furthermore, composites of PP30 and UiO-66-NH2 made from both PeBax 1657 and 2533 were placed in a sonicator for 15 min to determine how robust of an attachment existed between the MOF and fiber. As shown in b, some MOF stuck between fibers was removed from the substrate; however, a significant amount of MOF was still attached to the fiber for both composites. In particular, it appeared that more MOF was still attached to the composite made with PeBax2533; this was likely due to water partially dissolving the PeBax1657 adhesive during the sonication process.
elements.clean_text: Finally, the stability of the composites was assessed in two different ways. HKUST-1 is known to be unstable toward moisture (both liquid and vapor). The PP30/P1657_HKUST-1 composite was submerged in liquid water for 24 h; as shown by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data shown in a, there was no difference in patterns before and after liquid water exposure, and the long-range order peaks associated with HKUST-1 remain intact for the sample. Furthermore, composites of PP30 and UiO-66-NH2 made from both PeBax 1657 and 2533 were placed in a sonicator for 15 min to determine how robust of an attachment existed between the MOF and fiber. As shown in b, some MOF stuck between fibers was removed from the substrate; however, a significant amount of MOF was still attached to the fiber for both composites. In particular, it appeared that more MOF was still attached to the composite made with PeBax2533; this was likely due to water partially dissolving the PeBax1657 adhesive during the sonication process.

elements.content: (a) PXRD spectra for PP30/P1657_HKUST-1 before and after exposure to liquid water. (b) PP30 samples with PeBax and UiO-66-NH2 before and after sonication. Scale bar = 100 μm.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) PXRD spectra for PP30/P1657_HKUST-1 before and after exposure to liquid water. (b) PP30 samples with PeBax and UiO-66-NH2 before and after sonication. Scale bar = 100 μm.

elements.content: In conclusion, we demonstrated the ability to attach the MOFs UiO-66-NH2 and HKUST-1 to the inert PP substrate using PeBax as an adhesive. The type of PeBax used had an effect on both the performance of the composites against the mustard simulant CEES as well as the hydrophilicity/hydrophobicity of the fiber mat. The underlying density of the mat also had an effect on performance, with higher density mats providing increased protection against CEES. The strategy of using PeBax as an adhesive resulted in the stabilization of HKUST-1 to moisture as well as the ability to mix multiple MOFs onto the substrate. Overall, these materials show promise for personal protective equipment to protect against toxic chemicals, and further optimization and tuning can be conducted for specific/targeted toxic chemical removal.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we demonstrated the ability to attach the MOFs UiO-66-NH2 and HKUST-1 to the inert PP substrate using PeBax as an adhesive. The type of PeBax used had an effect on both the performance of the composites against the mustard simulant CEES as well as the hydrophilicity/hydrophobicity of the fiber mat. The underlying density of the mat also had an effect on performance, with higher density mats providing increased protection against CEES. The strategy of using PeBax as an adhesive resulted in the stabilization of HKUST-1 to moisture as well as the ability to mix multiple MOFs onto the substrate. Overall, these materials show promise for personal protective equipment to protect against toxic chemicals, and further optimization and tuning can be conducted for specific/targeted toxic chemical removal.

cln_elements.content:
The metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) UiO-66-NH2 and HKUST-1 were adhered to chemically inert polypropylene (PP) fibrous mats with poly­(ether-block-amide), aka PEBA or PeBax, using a phase inversion technique. Two types of PeBax were used to investigate the effects of a hydrophilic vs hydrophobic treatment on uptake and permeation properties of the chemical warfare agent simulant 2-chloroethyl ethyl sulfide (CEES). Furthermore, the underlying PP fiber density was altered to understand CEES permeation properties. It was found that using the hydrophobic PeBax 2533 and a higher fiber density led to better barrier properties, with the best material providing ∼250 min protection to a permeation rate of 0.1 μg/min/cm2 in comparison to ∼150 min for the activated carbon fiber Stedcarb. CEES uptake ranged from ∼1.0 to 2.4 mol/kg for composites in comparison to 3.6 mol/kg for the pure MOF. Furthermore, the technique allowed for incorporation of different MOFs, and even a mixture of MOFs, on the same fiber substrate. Finally, the PeBax formulation was able to stabilize HKUST-1 against moisture, potentially opening the door for applications of this MOF in high-humidity environments.

Photographic and SEM images of the resulting composites from 30 gsm fabric after drying are shown in (note: see Figure S2 for SEM images of 70 gsm samples). Composites made from both PeBax 1657 (a hydrophilic variant) and PeBax 2533 (a hydrophobic variant) both had good dispersion of MOF throughout the textile. The PeBax 2533 was more hydrophobic due to the higher organic content (e.g., longer carbon chains) within the structure, as shown in Figure S1. TGA data (Figure S3a) were collected to determine the mass of MOF within the composites, and N2 isotherm data (Figure S3b) were collected to determine MOF accessibility within the composite. TGA data indicate that composites made using PeBax 1657 behave more like the baseline PP, while composites made using PeBax 2533 had characteristics more like the baseline MOF, in terms of initial mass loss due to solvent and onset of degradation. The mass of MOF on composites made with PeBax 2533 was higher than those for PeBax 1657, potentially because of the hydrophobic nature of PeBax 2533 being a better match for the nonpolar PP. Nitrogen uptake was commensurate with the TGA data, with the PeBax 2533 samples having higher uptake than the PeBax 1657 samples. For both types of composite, the mass of MOF calculated based on surface areas (Table S1) almost exactly matched the amount of MOF calculated from TGA data (), indicating that PeBax does not block access to the MOF pores.
cln_elements.clean_text:
The metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) UiO-66-NH2 and HKUST-1 were adhered to chemically inert polypropylene (PP) fibrous mats with poly(ether-block-amide), aka PEBA or PeBax, using a phase inversion technique. Two types of PeBax were used to investigate the effects of a hydrophilic vs hydrophobic treatment on uptake and permeation properties of the chemical warfare agent simulant 2-chloroethyl ethyl sulfide (CEES). Furthermore, the underlying PP fiber density was altered to understand CEES permeation properties. It was found that using the hydrophobic PeBax 2533 and a higher fiber density led to better barrier properties, with the best material providing ~250 min protection to a permeation rate of 0.1 μg/min/cm2 in comparison to ~150 min for the activated carbon fiber Stedcarb. CEES uptake ranged from ~1.0 to 2.4 mol/kg for composites in comparison to 3.6 mol/kg for the pure MOF. Furthermore, the technique allowed for incorporation of different MOFs, and even a mixture of MOFs, on the same fiber substrate. Finally, the PeBax formulation was able to stabilize HKUST-1 against moisture, potentially opening the door for applications of this MOF in high-humidity environments.

Photographic and SEM images of the resulting composites from 30 gsm fabric after drying are shown in  (note: see Figure S2 for SEM images of 70 gsm samples). Composites made from both PeBax 1657 (a hydrophilic variant) and PeBax 2533 (a hydrophobic variant) both had good dispersion of MOF throughout the textile. The PeBax 2533 was more hydrophobic due to the higher organic content (e.g., longer carbon chains) within the structure, as shown in Figure S1. TGA data (Figure S3a) were collected to determine the mass of MOF within the composites, and N2 isotherm data (Figure S3b) were collected to determine MOF accessibility within the composite. TGA data indicate that composites made using PeBax 1657 behave more like the baseline PP, while composites made using PeBax 2533 had characteristics more like the baseline MOF, in terms of initial mass loss due to solvent and onset of degradation. The mass of MOF on composites made with PeBax 2533 was higher than those for PeBax 1657, potentially because of the hydrophobic nature of PeBax 2533 being a better match for the nonpolar PP. Nitrogen uptake was commensurate with the TGA data, with the PeBax 2533 samples having higher uptake than the PeBax 1657 samples. For both types of composite, the mass of MOF calculated based on surface areas (Table S1) almost exactly matched the amount of MOF calculated from TGA data (), indicating that PeBax does not block access to the MOF pores.

Table 1. MOF wt% in Composites Measured from TGA and N<sub>2</sub> Isotherm Data

| material | wt % MOF TGA | wt % MOF N<sub>2</sub> isotherm |
|----------|-------------|--------------------------------|
| PP30/P1657_UiO-66-NH<sub>2</sub> | 25 | 28 |
| PP70/P1657_UiO-66-NH<sub>2</sub> | 21 | 17 |

| PP70/P2533_UiO-66-NH<sub>2</sub> | 42 | 44 |
